abstract.text: We present recent results of hadronic B meson decays related to the CKM angle β. The data used were collected by the BABAR detector at the PEP-II asymmetricenergy e + e − collider operating at the Υ(4S) resonance located at the Stanford Linear Accelerator Center.

body_text.text: Introduction

The Standard Model (SM) of particle physics describes charge conjugationparity (CP ) violation as a consequence of a complex phase in the threegeneration Cabibbo-Kobayashi-Maskawa (CKM) quark-mixing matrix 1 . CP violation in B meson decays is described by the angles α, β and γ of the Unitarity Triangle. We describe here recent results from BABAR for the angle β, defined as arg [

The BABAR detector 2 is located at the SLAC PEP-II e + e − asymmetricenergy B-factory 3 . Data are collected at the Υ(4S) resonance.
These proceedings describe measurements of sin2β from B 0 → ccK 0 decays, sin2β from loop-dominated charmless B 0 decays and measurements of cos2β.

The sinusoidal term describes interference between B 0 − B 0 mixing and decay and the cosine term is the direct CP asymmetry. The BB pair created in the Υ(4S) decay evolves coherently. Therefore, determining the flavor (B 0 or B 0 ) of one B meson (B tag ) also determines the flavor of the other B at the time of the B tag decay. The second B will continue to oscillate between flavor states. The effective tagging efficiency is Q ≡ i ε i (1 − 2w i ) 2 = (30.4 ± 0.3) %, where the sum over i represents 6 mutually exclusive tagging categories, ε is the fraction of events in each category, and w is the fraction of incorrectly tagged events. The boosted center of mass allows for a measurement of the spatial separation of the B meson decay vertices to be converted into the proper time difference used in Eqn. 1.

sin2β from
The most precise measurement of β comes from B 0 → ccK 0 decays, where the b quark decays via the CKM-favored V cb transition to a ccs final state.

In these decays, S b→ccs = −η f sin2β, where η f is the CP eigenvalue of the final state 5 . A recent model-independent calculation finds an expected deviation of S b→ccs from −η f sin2β of 0.000 ± 0.017 6 .

sin2β from b → s Penguins

Decays of B 0 mesons to charmless hadronic final states such as η ′ K 0 proceed mostly via a single loop (penguin) amplitude. In the SM the penguin amplitude has approximately the same weak phase as the b → ccs transition, but it is sensitive to the possible presence of new physics due to heavy particles in the loop 8 . If the only contribution to these decays were from the dominant SM penguin processes, S b→s = −η f sin2β as in the b → ccs case. However, other decay processes can contribute as well. Pollution from non-leading order diagrams can cause S b→s = S b→ccs , or ∆S = 0, with ∆S ≡ S b→s − sin2β. SM predictions and theoretical uncertainties for ∆S range from ∼ −0.05 − +0.20 depending on the decay channel, 9,10,11,12 where the cleanest modes have ∆S ∼ 0.01 ± 0.01. Any further deviation of ∆S from zero could be due to the presence of new physics in the loop, which is not possible in the b → ccs case. Recent results from seven such b → s penguin-dominated decay channels are shown in Table 1.

As shown in Table 1, each measurement implies a negative value for ∆S. Moreover, the theoretical SM predictions for ∆S tend to be positive in nearly all cases. However, the uncertainties, both experimentally and theoretically, are still sufficiently large that no definite conclusions can be reached at this point. The single most precise measurement, that of B 0 → η ′ K 0 , now shows a deviation of 5.5σ from zero, which is the first observation of mixing-induced CP violation in a charmless B decay. The deviation from sin2β, however, is ∼ 1σ. No individual channel represents a deviation from sin2β > ∼ 2σ.
Measurements of cos2β

The measurement of sin2β leaves a 4-fold ambiguity in the value of β. This ambiguity can be partially resolved with a measurement of cos2β. The final state J/ψ K * 0 (K 0 S π 0 ) contains both CP -even and CP -odd components. A full angular analysis of this final state allows for the extraction of cos2β with the result cos2β > 0 with 86% confidence based on a data sample of 88 million BB pairs 20 .

Recently, two new technique have been used to deduce the sign of cos2β. Both B 0 and B 0 mesons decay to the final state D * + D * − K 0 S . A potential interference effect of the decay proceeding through an intermediate resonance can be measured by dividing the B-decay Dalitz plot into regions with 21 . The resulting measurement concludes cos2β > 0 with 94% confidence 22 in agreement with the result from J/ψ K * 0 . This result is based on a data sample of 230 million BB pairs.

A second new technique to determine the sign of cos2β utilizes the decay B 0 → D 0 (π + π − K 0 S )h 0 , which can occur with or without B 0 −B 0 mixing, where h 0 represents an η, η ′ , π 0 or ω meson. Interference effects are visible across the D 0 Dalitz plot 23 . A full Dalitz plot fit measures sin2β = 0.45±0.35±0.05±0.07 and cos2β = 0.54±0.54±0.08±0.18, where the first uncertainty is statistical, the second is systematic and the third is theoretical, based on a data sample of 311 million BB pairs. This result shows a preference for a solution of β over π/2 − β with 87% confidence 24 , in good agreement with the previously reported measurements.
Conclusions

A variety of recent measurements of the CKM angle β are reported from BABAR. The direct measurement of sin2β from b → ccs channels continues to be the most precise measurement. The sign of cos2β is now determined to be positive with at at least 86% confidence in three independent measurements.
